September is National Suicide Prevention Awareness Month. This month is a time to raise awareness, provide support and break down the stigma surrounding this very real issue. Suicidal thoughts can affect anyone regardless of age, gender or background. Suicide is preventable and each one of us can do out part to recognize the warning signs, show compassion and offer support to those who are struggling. Our goal is to raise awareness about this issue and connect those who may be struggling to the proper resources. People in crisis or having thoughts of suicide, or those who know someone who may be should do the following:
· National Suicide Prevention Hotline: 1-800-273-TALK (8255)
· Crisis Text Hotline: Text HOME to 741741
· Whatcom County Crisis and Triage Stabilization Center: 1-360-676-2020
· If there is an emergency dial 9-1-1
· Visit the link below for additional mental health treatment and support resources
https://www.whatcomcounty.us/DocumentCenter/View/28170/Accessing-Behavioral-Health-Services-2019?bidId=

A Message from Superintendent, Dr. James Everett:

This evening we were alerted to a video of a student making a statement about racism. We are unaware of the full context of the exchange and are looking into the matter. That said, it has had an impact on our students and our community. As a school district, we condemn racism and hatred of any kind. Against the backdrop of the crisis in our country of perpetual racism and inequality – the recent murder of George Floyd as well as other black citizens, we understand more than ever to stay silent would mean we were complicit.

We know we must do better as a society, community, and school district. We commit to engage, listen, and explore how inequities are enacted on some so we may fully support all of our students – regardless of their origin or color. We are deeply dedicated to all of our students and commit to being allies to our communities of color. Dialogue, together, is how we will grow and improve. Every student should have the assurance they are seen, valued, and loved.

“Thank you for your thoughts and prayers for Jolee. As many of you know she had an awkward collision on the basketball court last night. She was rushed to St. Joe’s as she immediately had no feeling in her left leg and then shortly thereafter her right arm. It took almost 2 hours before she regained feeling in both extremities. Your prayers were powerful as the CT scan was negative. As you can imagine, she is very stiff and sore. She will have a follow up this week with her Primary Dr. where we should have more information about her injury and recovery.
We thank you for your continued thoughts and prayers. Our Trojan community connection is amazing and we genuinely appreciate all of you for supporting all our athletes.”

This week Superintendent, Dr. Everett had the privilege to serve as a Watch D.O.G.S. at Irene Reither Elementary School. Dr. Everett said of the experience, “I gave (and received) plenty of high-fives, and was in awe of the skill and effort displayed by our teachers in their classrooms - and enjoyed being surrounded by positive adults focused on making the environment joyful and supportive for their students”. What is Watch D.O.G.S.?
WATCH D.O.G.S. (Dads Of Great Students) is an innovative father involvement, educational initiative of the National Center For Fathering.
Watch D.O.G.S. is not just for dads but also for grandfathers, uncles, adult older brothers and father figures.
If you or someone you know would be a great fit for Watch D.O.G.S. learn more and sign up at the link below!

School Bus Drivers

Every day in the United States, over 400,000 school buses transport approximately 25 million students between home and school. Collectively, school buses travel 4.3 billion miles each year. In Washington State, school buses provide over 700,000 student trips per day and travel over 100 million miles per year. When you consider field trips or activity trips, nearly every student rides a school bus at some point during the school year. Student transportation has the best safety record for any mode of ground-based, passenger transportation.

Last year, Meridian school buses safely transported 1600 students per day and drove over 500 extra-curricular trips for a total of 192,366 miles. Thanks for the great job our transportation staff does every day to keep our kids safe.

It was working as a teacher on special assignment when she realized she wanted to be able to make decisions for a school and also be part of a learning community that was fun and supported student growth. Meridian High School Contemporary World Problems classes, taught by Mr. Kurz and Mrs. Shumway, have been studying world cultures, heritages and religions.

Eitan Teiger, from standwithus.org, shared about the Israeli culture and his perspective on Israel's history, current role in the world and the Middle East.

On June 10, Kamalla Kaur from the Chardi Kala Project, along with Sikh musicians Bhai Sulakam Singh and Harjeet Singh- from the Gursikh Gurdwara Temple in Lynden, shared their knowledge and music of the Sikh religion.

We are grateful to these guest presenters for sharing their cultural insights. This important experience has helped our students to better understand and appreciate the world in which we live as well as the people we share it with.
